section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials To prepare, use a white resist crayon to write capital and lowercase Ee, Kk, and Ll on a white sheet, one letter per sheet of paper. Gather paintbrushes, heavily watered down blue and black paint, and On Ed’s Bed, The Kitchen, and The Little Lion.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read a story called The One Day House about a boy who gets help from adults to fix up Gigi’s house. We found the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll in the story.

Each of you has a secret letter on your paper. You’re going to paint your paper to find out what that letter is. Find the friend who has the same letter so that you will have one lowercase letter and one uppercase letter.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model/Teach Make sure children know which letter they have and the sound it makes. Depending on small group size, adjust amount of letters and partners as needed.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What letter do you have? What sound does that letter make?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Ask each pair of children the same question. Repeat with other groups of six. Have children find the book that matches the letter and read the book together.
Extend Have children think of other words that begin with their letter, or draw a picture of something that begins with their letter.

Talk About Letters and Words After all children have had a turn painting to uncover their letters, play a game where you open a children’s dictionary to one of the letters and read a word they may know. Let children volunteer to tell you what the word means.
Instead of reading the book, have children find their assigned letters in their matching book. Provide support prompts such as “Does elephant have an e in it? Can you point to the letters?”

If children would benefit from an extra challenge, provide them with words containing all three letters. Ask which letter it starts with, ends with, and which is in the middle. Examples: lake, elk, kale, keel, leak,and leek.

If you feel some multilingual learners in your class are advanced, prepare beforehand by researching words in their language that feature all three letters, and have them complete the challenge activity. You may need to reinforce the meaning of the words/phrases starts with, middle, and ends with.
Children may require additional support with painting their papers. Provide assistance by modeling how to hold your paintbrush and the appropriate way to dip your paintbrush in the paint.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read about how Wilson took initiative and asked for help to fix Gigi’s house. We read about how Wilson found problems in Gigi’s house and planned how to solve the problems.

Today we’re going to work together to solve problems. Each of these cards shows a problem. Your job is to say what the problem is and how you would solve it! You will work with a partner. When we’re done, we’ll share the problems and how we’ll solve the problems.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model/Teach Advise children that when they try to identify the problem, they can ask “What is wrong here?” To solve the problem, ask “How would I fix what is wrong?”
Ask Circulate as pairs work on their problems and solutions. Ask, What problem are you trying to solve?

Extend If time permits, allow partners to switch cards and think of alternative solutions. Have the pair compare their solutions and then share their ideas with the rest of the class. Compare to see if each pair thought of a different solution, and discuss each option. Allow the class to vote on the best solution.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Sometimes a problem might be too hard to solve by ourselves. What do we do if we can’t solve the problem by ourselves? Why did Wilson ask for help? What could happen if we ask for help?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Some children may have difficulty coming up with a solution, while others may not be able to conceptualize consequences of their solution on others. In either case, offering these children two or three solutions can help. Ask them to choose the best one.
If children find a solution to their problem very quickly, ask them to think of alternate solutions. Ask: What if you wanted to fix it another way? What else could you do?

Match sentence and vocabulary complexity to multilingual learners’ level of understanding of English. When describing scenarios, use simple phrases with children who are new to learning English and more complex phrases as they learn the language.

At this age, many children are still learning to say their /r/ sounds, as well as to blend consonants. Help children by focusing on the word “problem.” Hold the card close to you and ask, What problem are you trying to solve? This will help children focus on how your mouth moves as you say the word.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need On Ed’s Bed, The Kitchen, The Little Lion, and drawing supplies for this activity.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The One Day House, we found the words that begin with e, k, and l. Who can remember words in the story that began with the letter e? The letter k? The letter l?
Today we’re going to reread On Ed’s Bed, The Kitchen, and The Little Lion and create stories together with the words we see at the end of the book.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Discuss Write down and read aloud the words on the back cover of On Ed’s Bed. Provide children with drawing supplies. Say: Let’s create a new story together about the words that start with e.
Write Invite children to write and draw the story on their paper as you create your story together.
Repeat Continue this activity with The Kitchen and words that start with k and The Little Lion and words that start with l.

Share Stories and Practice Writing Ee, Kk, and Ll Invite children to share their written products with the group. Then encourage children to practice writing the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll. Ask: What was your favorite story we wrote today? What new letter would you like to write a story about?

Focus on just one letter instead of all three and guide children through each step of creating a story and involving words that begin with chosen letter. Reread the Alphabet Book and have children identify the beginning letter of each specified word.

Challenge children to create a story about a new letter of their choice. Invite children to list words that begin with their chosen letter and create a story, using those words. Challenge the group to each select a different letter.

Be aware that the letter k is a foreign letter in the Spanish language and used only in words from other languages. Take time, as needed, to review the English phonemes /ĕ/, /ē/, /k/, and /l/ and have children say the sounds with you.

Be aware when children seem to be emotionally or academically “overloaded” during small group activities. Take a moment for children to stretch and move to help them find control and attend to the activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need markers and paper. Before children arrive, doodle across the page with a black marker, so that shapes are created for children to color. Place markers in front of children’s seats.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we talked about things we do better together. The rabbits made soup better together. Wilson made Gigi’s house better together by working together.

Now it’s our turn! Let’s work on making something better together. You will use the color marker in front of you to color in all these shapes! When I give the signal, move to a new spot on the table. Let’s practice.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Have children gather around the table. Come up with a recognizable signal to use such as clapping your hands, chanting “teamwork makes the dream work,” or raising your hand.
Ask Remind children to keep coloring during their turns. Allow for giggles as they move from seat to seat, coloring in the chart.
Repeat Repeat the cycle of clapping and having children move until the entire page is colored. You may help if time is short.

Talk About Working Together Ask children why working together on this project was better than working alone. Then, ask: What other jobs around the classroom do we do better together? Provide hints as needed to lead children to other answers: cleaning up, lining up, singing loudly, talking, writing stories, or playing pretend.

Children may argue as they work together. Before beginning, tell children that working together can be difficult and work out a strategy for dealing with frustrations that may arise. Remind them to use their problem-solving skills.

Challenge children to move positions by themselves without waiting for the signal. Have children to think about how they as a group can be most effective in finishing their project. Encourage children to think about which direction they’ll move and when they’ll change positions.

Extended conversation plays a critical role in helping multilingual learners to acquire a new language. One way to support children is by using oral conversation frames that repeat part of the question in the answer. For example: “What is teamwork? Teamwork is working together.” Have children say the frames with you. Then have partners use the frames to ask and answer questions with each other.

Many children who struggle with attention disorders can fall into a state of hyperfocus. If you have a child in your class who tends to do this, a project like this one may be daunting: they may resent having to move from their “shape” before they have completed it in order to move on. Trust your judgment in approaching transitions.
